lines: On a warm Saturday afternoon, a young neighborhood kid challenges you to a strenuous physical competition.

You still have it in you. You huff and puff your way to victory. The kid smiles and puts his arm around your shoulder. It's been a while since you've done something like this. As you relish the thought that the old locomotive is
still pumping as strong as ever, the kid tries to make you think he let you win.

You must be losing it. You remember a time when you outran, outjumped, outhurdled, outboxed and outbragged little guys like him. Now he's got it over you. When the game is over, he puts his arm around your shoulder and smiles.
What you've given up in victory, you may have gained emotionally. You are a good sport.
A bit scared, perhaps? Whatsamatter, old fella, can't take a little good-natured competition? He challenges you again.
Where's that fighting spirit? I guess you don't feel like you have to prove anything these days.
